These may only be relevant to autonomy

Review Title: Probably one of the best places to work
Pros: The company makes extremely good use of employee engagement surveys. Every single piece of critical constructive feedback I've given has been acted on. The Cloud Apps Director and Principal Engineer Team Leads at this company show that they care for individuals with their actions, and are open-minded continuous learners who lead by example. Amazing benefits package. The company seems healthy and successful despite challenging economic times. C-level and VP-level leadership is doing an amazingly good job.
Cons: This is a tough industry to be in. The work can be demanding (but for those who genuinely want to learn and grow in their career, there is no shortage of room to grow). Grit, courage, and self-driven continuous learner mentality is a requirement for this company, which isn't a con per se, but sometimes conditions are ambiguous and challenging in innovation spaces during uncertain economy. Internal team compositions are sometimes awkward when working across teams, which isn't horrible but there's room for improvement that can make our need for agility and cross-functional knowledge-work less demanding.

Pros: The company has always supported my goals and has mentored me to be the best I can be. Not just for the company but can be translated into anything life has for me. I want to grow with the company for as long as they will have me and I am provided the tools to get me there. I am often rewarded or recognized by management and by my peers, I did not have that with previous employers and that means a lot to me.
Cons: I wish they offered Kaiser Permanente Medical Insurance

Pros: Like all companies, the company culture means nothing if you have a great or horrible manager. In Motional's case, in my experience, there's good company culture and my manager is wonderful as well. I have the freedom to make an impact, and am encouraged to do so. I see negative reviews online (on Blind, for example) before I joined motional about how they are not confident about the company. I have worked for other AV companies. Motional is clearly not the leader in the AV space, but it isn't the worst either. It has huge backing from Mega players like Hyundai and Aptiv, which means A LOT, and we're accelerating towards delivering driverless vehicles in several cities very soon. Their pay structure is also good, with lots of stocks too, (unlike some other places where the stocks will expire if you leave, etc). Work life balance is relatively better, compared to all other AV companies I have heard (or worked) for, which actually results in better efficiency of employees so they can get actually more work done, instead of being forced to slave away for long, inefficient, hours.
Cons: Like all AV companies, this is a new , huge and challenging problem that we all are trying hard to solve for the first time ever. So better planning and foresight can go a long way in increasing efficiency.

Cons: The negative reviews on here shouldn’t be a surprise to the company by now. Some of them have been voiced in yearly survey reviews (the results of which are not always announced or in their entirety..). If there was genuine interest for a solution, they would have done *something*, instead of deferring people here to talk to HR. As another recent comment here said, people might reasonably be afraid to talk to HR in fears of being singled out. Career growth is vague and not transparent, managers get promoted without having advanced their team, people with limited experience hold senior roles. Certain questions (that happen to be unfavorable to management) aren’t approved/addressed in company-wide meetings. It is a pity, the culture used to be wonderful.

The people running this place truly are pathetic in an ocean gate mentally kinda way. Beware.

Review Title: The place is great...but not for every profession.
Pros: - Your work will be with the best in the world on the cutting edge, which will definitely change the world for the better. - People are mostly very kind and open to sharing their know-how and insights. - Relatively good compensation. Good perks and insurance coverage. Generous PTO. - Autonomous vehicles are cool in every sense of the word.
Cons: - We are not ready for autonomous vehicles, especially those that are superior to level 3. It's not the technology, but rather the regulations and authorities. It may take quarters or years for your hard work to be widely known. - The company is extremely engineering-friendly. Any other profession could suffer from the unbalanced culture dominated by engineers. - In common with many automotive companies, the company also suffers from dependencies and misaligned goals, since many teams work in silos. - Collaboration between Singapore and the East Coast of the US may impair work-life balance in a negative way. - Leadership could be hypocritical as teams other than engineering functions could be involutional now. You can't expect too much on career development, if you are not an engineer.

Review Title: Company is becoming better each day.
Pros: * Company tries to operate based on the core values. These values help drive the goals/objectives which in turn foster more focused and collective efforts by employees. * Many things are not top-notched but I do see things becoming better each day. * Company is helpful for all kind of work-related visa! * Company seems to have a good relationship with Lyft and Uber.
Cons: * For employee who has been with the company longer, maybe it is harder to get significant number of stocks/shares as opposed to someone who just joined that typically get a significant more number of shares in the company. * It can be hard to get green card sponsorship by the company and the HR handling the matter is not the most helpful and approachable. * Company still seems to have a long way to catch up to competitors like Waymo and Cruise. * Company does not have it own ride-hailing app like what Waymo and Cruise are having. Not sure if this will be good or bad in the long run. For now, I feel it could be a potential minor con assuming Waymo and Cruise have better business model.

Review Title: It's a great place to work!
Pros: I'll start with mentioning I'm biased because I prefer a start-up culture where there are opportunities to take more initiative and have a greater influence over the end product. Motional definitely allows individuals to take ownership of their work and drive solutions cross-functionally across the organization. The leadership are good at being transparent about issues that we're facing and helping solve challenges head-on rather than shying away. Everyone is very open and supportive. There's a solid culture for working together and helping each other rather than just trying to "climb the corporate ladder".
Cons: There are some challenges with overlapping responsibilities and roles across teams. Because every team is empowered to take initiative, many times there are multiple teams that end up working on similar things and duplicating work if they don't coordinate. There's also having "too many cooks in the kitchen". Sometimes many people want to provide their opinion which can inhibit progress from being accomplished. It's nice to have data to make decisions, but sometimes if the data does not exist engineers will struggle to make the best decision possible with the data that is available.

Pros: The unlimited PTO seems to actually be unlimited (obviously within reason). I missed a little over a week with an illness within my first 2 months, and it was not an issue at all. I also have a little vacation time off around the Christmas holiday that isn't an issue either, so I'll have used 2 weeks PTO in my first 2 months. Everyone that I've worked with has been friendly and helpful, both within and outside my team. Everyone that I've worked with has also been very knowledgeable on what they are working on.
Cons: There's a lack of company process, but that is a common thing with startups. This can be a pro and a con, but I've listed it under cons because Motional is working on a safety critical product in a regulated industry. There does seem to be a good understanding of and reliance on ISO-26262, but there aren't a lot of company processes that define the specific implementation of ISO-26262 that Motional wants to follow.

Review Title: Tons of Inertia - For better or worse
Pros: Motional leaders seem to be generally willing to allow contributors to innovate and pursue ideas they find compelling. There is tremendous flexibility and ability to get the job done however the individual sees fit. Surprisingly for a company of its size and with so much influence/investment by major legacy corporations, there is not a lot of needless process and red tape over relatively trivial things. Overall, the attitude seems generally positive, the diversity of people is relatively strong, and the breadth of the company means there is tremendous opportunity for those who wish to find it. The amount of funding Motional has accrued at this point in 2022 has enabled it to become a relatively large company for AV, which even in light of some points of concern instills confidence in the survival of the company for long enough to really begin to truly scale the technology.
Cons: Unfortunately, the evolution of Motional as the confluence of several startups and contributions from an automotive OEM and Tier One supplier show...there is a head-scratching amount of work that is lost and redone between product iterations. There are, also, a surprising number of technical capabilities that younger and/or much smaller companies have already attained that Motional has not. A surprisingly dogmatic approach to technology development (ML models for everything!) restricts the pace of advancement and makes for endless headaches on the part of Validation and test teams. Because Motional has only now begun really investing in commercial partnerships (the prior deployment in Las Vegas was really treated as a side show in a lot of ways), it has relatively informal and lax practices and policies around public-facing operations (though, it should be said, not with respect to safety). The extraordinarily conservative nature of the product design (a safety driver AND a safety operator in every vehicle) makes the path to driverless - a goal toward which all AV companies are working - a steep one, even relative to industry peers. The biggest con, in my opinion, is that the lack of structure creates a lot of confusion and churn, and then an incredible amount of duplicated work. It also leads to strained relationships across functions, when the work one group does is not adequately communicated to another, and then priorities/work/finished product conflicts.

Review Title: Great Workplace Environment with Exciting Challenges
Pros: At Motional you can truly feel like you are making a difference by contributing to challenging problems. The teams are collaborative, leadership is supportive, and the people are friendly. Motional also values work-life balance and demonstrates true value in its employees.
Cons: At times, tasks can seem overwhelming or ambiguous due to the challenging nature of the work but there is always a team around to support you.

Pros: The people at Motional are some of the best in the world. When there are gaps in process or technical hurdles, everyone rallies to create a solution. I've also never seen such a diverse workforce in a tech company (of any size).
Cons: Growth of the employee base has outpaced process, so some process gaps lead to frustration.

2- Easy going coworkers (for the most part)

Cons:

BD teams were perhaps too effective at securing external partnerships for deployments. Strong financial backing from Hyundai (pay was pretty good for a non-costal job).
Cons:
Program management operated in an extremely myopic fashion; was very clear the program managers in charge were more concerned with having a good 'scorecard' rather than fostering the development of a scalable product.

Despite the strong financial backing of Hyundai, the working relationship was very dysfunctional in most areas, especially engineering and with regard to communication (downplaying) of risks.

I've never seen an HR org more drunk on wokeness & power (and I've worked at Google).
